I owned the RG351M. Sent the original back and the UK supplier replaced it because one of the shoulder buttons stopped working. Sent the replacement back because of dead pixels. The Anbernic console is uncomfortable to use for someone with large hands and it wasn't powerful enough to play anything past the original PlayStation games and even then some of the games such as Legacy of Kane would stutter. Most N64 games seemed to run well and I could get some decent performance for Dreamcast ROM's.

I know there are more powerful Anbernic devices now but for me the form factor is too small, the analogue sticks are in an uncomfortable position and the build quality was shit. PS Vita can do much more, is more ergonomic and has great scene support.

>>91222032
-vf "[0:0]scale=480:-1:force_original_aspect_ratio=1[a];[a]pad=480:272:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2[b]"

this is probably most important and complex filter you need for psp encodes if you ever run into uneven resolutions that cause wrong downscale. psp will freak out if you get unsupported resolution even if one pixel if wrong. so adding arbitrary padding is important
also make sure you use SYNC on linux when transferring files. psp really dumb when it comes to safety removal

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91197059
When React renders out that div in to the DOM, it calls `props.ref(value)` with the HTML DOM element, so that you can access it and do stuff with it like get dimensions of the element.

Since you're looping a bunch of elements, you're storing it in an array like `allTheRefs`, so that you can later loop through the HTML elements and do stuff.

>>91197121
I'm confused by using an arrow in here: ref={ref => allTheRefs[item.id] = ref}
is that a Javascript syntax or specifically React?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91197230
Anything in between "{" ... "}" is JS syntax. This is an arrow function

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/Arrow_functions

These are basically the same:

<div
  ref={(ref) => {
    allTheRefs[item.id] = ref;
   }}
/>
<div
  ref={function(ref) {
    allTheRefs[item.id] = ref;
   }}
/>

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91200758
>>91200852
Just adding to this, generally speaking you should avoid using for..in-loops. There are legitimate uses for it, but they're all advanced use cases.
Instead, if you want to loop over just the keys of an object use 
for (const key of Object.keys(obj))
, and if you want to iterate over both keys and values use 
for (const [key, value] of Object.entries(obj))
. Furthermore, prefer using proper collections such as Map<K, V> or Set<V> instead of plain objects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91215288
They probably use 32 bit integers because of 32 bit computers. So it is possible to load and process the time in one go.

This is not required, you can have data types that are much larger than the registers of the processor by processing them in many steps.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arbitrary-precision_arithmetic

But they often use an integral data type (a "native" data type) like 32 bit on 32 bit CPU and then the Year 2038 problem arises.

>>91222022
Sure. Your hardware is still decent but for the last few "graphics hog" releases.

>I prefer the 65W TDP on the X600 chips to the extra performance of something like a 5800X3D
Just FYI the TDP figures are basically meaningless. The PPT on the 5600 is 88W but it only pulls c. 40W while gaming. The PPT on the X3D is 142W but, again, that's only for an all-core workload. The difference in gaming will be much smaller. Maybe even lower if the IO die isn't pushed as hard on account of the cache.
In summary, ignore the power differences. Even for all-core work the efficiency is broadly similar (but don't buy either if you do all-core work). The real question is whether the 3D cache would benefit the games you actually play. Read some benchmarks and judge whether it's worth the upfront cost. My personal take is that it'd be worth it if you intend to upgrade the card later and/or if you play some games that really like the cache. If your next upgrade is going to be a new platform then the 5600 is better value.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91199054
I recommend starting with MySQL because it's widely used (a lot of discussion and help available) and you can use it for other projects too, it's free. It's also more standard than the Microsoft version. If you have a specific job or company in mind, check their stack and learn that too, it won't take very long.
I think PowerBI is the most commonly used bi tool, I'm not really sure but it seems you can't wrong with that.
As for cloud, it really depends on the company, but AWS is the most popular one, like half the internet runs on it.

Anyway, prioritize learning SQL first. Solid SQL knowledge may get you the job on its own.

Next think of some subject matter area you are familiar with or have interest in. Ei banking and finance or Healthcare or even visya for that matter and try to find some analytics case studies from there.

Next step would be to figure out if you want to grow as analyst or move into engineering space. Both have pros and cons.

Pros of engineering is that they is likely to be higher, cons are you'd have to work with more spergs and customers are retarded.

Pros of analytics is that it is arguably easier to get into management and you have a better view of how your work contributes to organisation, cons is that engineering would have spergs who will not understand your use case.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91215982
If you sit around writing "design documents" you will never get anything finished. Design documents are written by non-technical people for a team of programmers so they understand the common goal, or so they can write code that fulfils those design parameters, or at least have a good reason why the design is fucking stupid and will never work.
If you are a single developer working on a project by yourself, AT BEST you need a 5-10 bullet point list of things your program needs to accomplish. The "design" phase should take an hour tops before you start just writing code and getting shit done.
For games the most important thing is playing it. You can write down shit that sounds fun all day long, but the reality is that 90% of the shit you come up with wont even actually be fun to play, so its much more productive to just actually create shit and try it and see if it sucks rather than obsess over writing dumb bullshit down and designing towards it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91199127
BTRFS (snapper) or ZFS
(LVM too but that's yucky when BTRFS and ZFS exist)
If you didn't set your system up that way to start with then "Fuck You".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91199178
How does that work?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91199192
The filesystems have built-in support for snapshotting so at any time you want you can create a snapshot of your entire system. If something fucks up or you just want to rollback your system for shits and giggles you can select an older snapshot from your bootloader.

Without built-in support for snapshots your only option is to image the entire drive with something like dd and restore that image if anything goes wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91199223
I see, and is there a tool to do this?
Also what's the difference between zfs and btrfs?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91199250
>Also what's the difference between zfs and btrfs?
Besides being two different filesystems with different codebases and different licenses (BTRFS is GPL, ZFS came from Oracle so has some weird CDDL license: https://openzfs.github.io/openzfs-docs/License.html), not a lot.

BTRFS supports some features ZFS doesn't (like reflinks that allow you to make a snapshot of an individual file) but other than that, most features one supports are supported by the other too.

What benefits I get from using btrfs snapshot over rsync?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91200103
It's done at a filesystem level which means BTRFS can more intelligently store data (only the differentials between each snapshot are stored). Rsync can't do that, the best it can do is hardlink files to try to save space.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91200780
Ah, you've just discovered the magic of file chooser portals!

The application doesn't actually have access to your files/folders (at least if you can't navigate to it in file:///home/USER it doesn't).

What's happening there is when you download something it fires off a Dbus request to the XDG Portal which opens an out-of-process (not running under Chromium) file chooser dialog.

When you select the directory the process hands back a file descriptor (at least I think that's how it works) to Chromium so that it can access the file/folder you selected.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91207444
>>91210488
This is extremely inaccurate. Nix (and Guix) are among the most easily customizable package managers there are.
They're usually compared to Gentoo if you want a rough idea.

Contrary to what some think they are source-based and the package manager is programmable, so you can literally write a 1-line shell command that "inherits" a package and makes a small change to, say, the make or configure flags, or the software version, and then it'll build it from source.

There's no limit to how complex those modifications can be, I only mentioned doing it on 1-line in a shell to give you an idea of how easy it can be. But you can make it a full file if you want, or put it inside your system declaration.
Nix (and Guix) have no limits to the customization you can do, and they come with functionality for quickly modifying them.

There are some downsides too. But lacking customization is absolutely NOT one of them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91211670
This question here mostly addresses the downsides of Nix (and Guix).
It's not like flatpack at all, because it doesn't work on "runtimes".

You never have redundant libraries, but if you have 2 applications that _require_ 2 different versions of a library then you'll have 2 versions of that library installed.
Personally I think that's a good thing, but some may consider it "bloat" since your average package manager would just use 1 version of the library and pray for the best.
Note that I emphasized _require_, because it's not an explicit requirement of the applications then they'll default to the latest version, in which case you'll only have 1 version of the lib.

>how big are the packages, do they come with bloat?
They're source-based package managers, so the packages you get are basically as-is straight from the developer. The package is only as big as the developer intends it to be.

>how does it work?
It helps to think recursively.
Basically each packages name is a hash of the exact build-chain (plus some other things like configure-flags, etc).

So when you build a package (packageA) that depends on another, say packageB, it has to compute the hash for packageB so it looks inside that package. Then say packageB depends on packageC, then it has to look inside packageC.
Then it would compute the hash (hashC) for packageC and pass that back to packageB which is now a PART of the hash for packageB (hashB), which is then now a part of the hash for packageA (hashA).
Then tomorrow if you go to upgrade the system it'll re-compute the hashes but say hashC changes, then hashB also changes, so packageA will need to be re-built.

In contrast to normal distros they wouldn't catch the change in packageC, because that's like a dependency-of-a-dependency.
So that's why with normal distros over time your software can deviate from what you'd get on a fresh install because it doesn't deal with the deeper dependencies of dependencies of dependencies.
Nix and Guix do.

This AI does NOT infact prove the retarded dubfag argument about japanese sounding "unfamiliar" or "alien" to people because of them not being used to it.

This is does indeed prove that western voice actors are not nearly as incometent as they seem at first, but it's not really an argument in favor of dubbing, because no matter how hard you try the dub will simply never work because of the difference in the way the languages sound.
English is unironically less expressive and is in general shittier sounding than japanese.

THERE'S A "GOES TO" OPERATOR?

https://cppquiz.org/quiz/question/333

No, it is an elaborate troll.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1642028/what-is-the-operator-in-c

It is in fact, two separate operators.
--> is not an operator. It is in fact two separate operators, -- and >.

The conditional's code decrements x, while returning x's original (not decremented) value, and then compares the original value with 0 using the > operator.

To better understand, the statement could be written as follows:

while( (x--) > 0 )

pick a number, add it to the list and save it as the start of a running total.
pick another number, if it would make your sum bigger than the target, flip the sign, add it to the list, update the sum.
repeat until you've got x-1 numbers, then subtract the sum from y to get your last number.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91217870
dd will literally take EVERY SINGLE 1 AND 0 from the source drive and put it on the destination drive EXACTLY how it was

dd stands for Duplicate Disk
it will take your drive in its exact configuration with everything on it and put it onto another drive in exactly the same way. this includes all partitions, filesystem tables, boot flags, EVERYTHING. it will literally ctrl + c and ctrl + v your HDD

download whatever linux bootale live iso you want and use rufus to put it on a usb
boot from that usb
run "lsblk" to find the names of your two drives
the dd command will look like this
dd if=/dev/sda of=/dev/sdb bs=4M conv=fsync,noerror
the bs=4M makes it copy 4 megabyte chunks at a time which is faster
conv=fsync,noerror just means it wont shit itself if anything happens during the operation

i can almost GARUNTEE that macrium reflect, under all the gloss, just uses a dd command (or whatever the DOS equivalent is)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91221802
cp doesn't copy filesystems or partitions, only data stored on a filesystem. you would need to first create the paritions, format them to your desired filesystem, and then copy each partition over one at a time. for windows, there are three partitions, the boot, data and recovery partitions.

cp also doesn't necessarily copy permissions, file dates, or some other metadatas, and doesn't do checks like dd does with fsync. cp is great for copying files, but not for Duplicating Disks.

and actually even for copying files cp isn't that great anymore, rsync is usually better in every situation that isn't just copying a handful of files to or from a download folder.

so the simplest way is still actually dd

Not dd specific, but on the topic of cloning disks.
After cloning a disk, do NOT boot with both the original and cloned disk in the same system.
Their block device IDs are the same which causes some filesystems (btrfs) to corrupt.
Not sure what would happen with i.e. ext4, since the fstab would be ambiguous.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91211767
Ok anon I'm in a good mood this morning so I'll spoon feed you. Your old hdd won't clone because it has bad sectors, so you'll want to use ddrescue to clone it. I see others have recommended that as well but I'll give you clear instructions.

Ok first you'll need put the source and the target drives in the Mac Pro (or whatever you're gonna use to clone them) and boot up that machine to a Linux live distro or 3rd drive that has Linux on it. Obviously you'll want to make sure this has ddrescue installed too.

Now, use another tool called gsmartcontrol to identify your drives, and you'll be able to see the bad sectors and other problems in a nice GUI. You can also just use the terminal and smartctl -a to do this but it's not as nice.

Next, use this command, assuming sda is your bad drive and sdb is the good drive. Please don't be a dumbass and get these switched irl, make sure the values actually correspond to the right drives or you're gonna have a bad time:

Ddrescue -v -v -b 4096 -f /dev/sda /dev/sdb ~/Desktop/clonelog.log

This will write a "map file" to your desktop, if the clone stops or gets stuck, you can unplug and replug the drives and run the command again referencing that file and it'll keep going where you left off. You can also run it in reverse etc to get as many bad sectors as you can.

Good luck anon

>>91205956
The real excitement I think is that these are literally first gen devices. Nothing about the technology itself, at least in my admittedly limited understanding, precludes scaling over both area and thickness, or their combined use with those new AI designed alien looking heatsinks.

As it stands, they're trying to target a very specific market segment of ultrathin notebooks, but I can easily a larger version of this, think 2 of the 15W versions stacked 3 layers high for a total of 6 jets, but instead of relying solely on the cooling within the chamber, they're pumping the air through an ultrafine mesh of copper wire as a heatsink. Current heaksink design can't get too fine or narrow because classic fans can't produce the pressure necessary to maintain airflow through them, but these could.

Ostensibly, we could get single slot blowers that are very cool and quiet despite pulling 300W+. Also, if they can really get the costs on the smaller 5W ones to the price of a regular fan, then I can certainly see my using a few of them as needed on VRMs, backplate hotspots, NVME drives etc.

Always nice to see new tech.

>Pic related. The dense mesh had way more cooling capacity but they couldn't get any real airflow through it at even their maximum pressure. The airjet would put out over 100times the pressure tested here, and should be able to get flow through a mesh. Link here: http://www.qualifiedrapidproducts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Mesh-heatsink-experiment-01.pdf

posts.sub: I'm frustrated with rust and tempted to retreat to C++...
posts.com:
WARNING!!! rant alert! Please don't flame just because I have a different (maybe wrong and miseducated idk) opinion.

I've been experimenting with Rust for over a month and I've still haven't mastered things like ownership and lifetimes... As per my experience rust requires you to use an insane workarounds for doing the simplest of things such as passing a variable to and from a thread or having mutable global variables.

lets take this simple code in rust and in C++

C++:
 #include <iostream>
#include <string>

std::string thing = "this";

int main() {
  std::cout << thing << std::endl;
  thing = std::string("other");
  std::cout << thing << std::endl;
}

posts.com:
Rust does not require "workarounds". Rust requires you to rethink your design, because it was probably bad to begin with. Every time someone complains about Rust, it's because they're using some design pattern invented for object oriented programming, which doesn't pay much attention to who owns what. Everyone's just sharing a bunch of mutable references to a bunch of objects, and if something mutates something it wasn't supposed to at the wrong time, that's life. Try sharing less. Figure out who is supposed to own what data at what times, and why. Don't think in terms of design patterns -- in fact, take your OOP design patterns book, and burn it. Just think about the data.

And for what it's worth, you can have global mutable variables. You just need unsafe. And you should think about why that might be unsafe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It isn't just about multithreading, it also prevents iterator invalidation-type problems. Take this code:
static mut text: String = String::new();

fn clear_the_string() {
    unsafe {
        text = String::new();
    }
}

fn main() {
    unsafe {
        text.push_str("abc");
        let byte = &text.as_bytes()[0];
        dbg!(*byte);
        clear_the_string();
        dbg!(*byte);
    }
}

[src/main.rs:13] *byte = 97
[src/main.rs:15] *byte = 0

After clearing the string the byte reference points to freed memory. That's undefined behavior.
The compiler can't detect this. It'd have to track that clear_the_string() modified the static and so can't be called while it's still borrowed, but that's infeasible in general.
So it's never allowed, not even in single-threaded programs.

I actually don't know a ton about Go but it seems they changed the default from 1 to the number of CPUs in Go 1.5: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1At2Ls5_fhJQ59kDK2DFVhFu3g5mATSXqqV5QrxinasI
The Go playground uses 8: https://go.dev/play/p/j8BLwa13U7I
They're more callous about data races than I expected:
>There is one non-performance concern. Increased parallelism could make bugs in racy programs more likely to cause crashes or other problems. The setting of GOMAXPROCS=1 may have thus far let those bugs go undetected. Raising it may therefore make buggy programs less reliable. We hope that both the race detector and the introduction of goroutine preemption and interleaving in Go 1.1 has already helped programmers identify and eliminate many such bugs. In any event, we can’t reasonably hobble the performance of working Go programs for fear of breaking buggy ones. If such buggy programs do turn up, the authors can set GOMAXPROCS=1 explicitly to keep them working until the bugs can be fixed.
You could see that as a rejection of the JS model. They consider code buggy even if it's correct on one system thread.
And I'm not sure how much code you could even write that's correct on one system thread but incorrect on multiple, since unlike JS you don't explicitly choose when to suspend. So for logical correctness you'd often still want synchronization, even if you're protected from data races. (Python's threading has the same problem despite the GIL, though its async doesn't.)

>>91222466
It is pretty messy, maybe I overstated.
They're still a good option for types that you can't construct at compile time (including anything that allocates), particularly if you don't need to modify the value afterwards.
Though the new hotness for that is once_cell, which is less magical than lazy_static: https://docs.rs/once_cell/latest/once_cell/sync/struct.Lazy.html
once_cell is being added to the standard library. Part of it will probably be released in 1.69, three months from now. (But not yet the Lazy type, so you have to use a OnceCell and call the get_or_init() method.)
So yeah, there's lots to be unhappy with. But it's not so bad that you need third party libraries to use static variables at all.
It's tricky. C++ tried to make it nice and intuitive and ended up with the static initialization order fiasco.

>>91222590
For complex objects you'd be able to shoot yourself in the foot if it didn't prohibit this, see >>91221278.
But for simple values it could be better. There's no reason this has to be disallowed in a single-threaded context:
use std::cell::Cell;

static VAR: Cell<i32> = Cell::new(0);

fn main() {
    let old = VAR.get();
    VAR.set(old + 1);
    println!("{}", VAR.get());
}

posts.name: The Falcon
posts.com:
>>91218196
So you want to learn programming?

Pick a starting language. For beginners, there are generally two recommended "programming families" that you can choose to start learning:
-Dynamically typed/interpreted programming languages, such as: Python, Javascript
-Statically typed/compiled programming languages, such as: C, C++, Java, C#

These are amongst the most popular languages in use worldwide (all in the top 10). Both approaches are perfectly fine, and well-documented.
-Dynamically typed programming may be a bit more flexible, convenient, and forgiving. It is more popular in academia.
-Statically typed programming is a bit more suited for making general applications. It is more popular in industries.

Cannot decide? Flip a coin.

If you choose statically typed/compiled programming, you may want to start with C, then pick up C++. C is very well documented, and teaches many universal programming concepts. C++ is based on C, and adds new concepts. Sources:
For C:
The C Programming Language (K&R)
C Primer Plus (Prata)
http://www.cprogramming.com/tutorial/c-tutorial.html
http://www.learn-c.org/

For C++:
http://www.learncpp.com/
http://www.cplusplus.com/doc/tutorial/
http://www.cprogramming.com/tutorial/c++-tutorial.html
http://en.cppreference.com/
https://isocpp.org/faq

If you choose dynamically typed/interpreted programming, you may want to start with Python. It is very easy to pick up. Here are some good sources:
http://www.learnpython.org/
https://www.codecademy.com/catalog/language/python

>BUT I WANT MORE SOURCES!
Read: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/index.php/Programming_resources

>BUT I WANNA START WITH [language x] INSTEAD!
Sure, if you like. But the languages above are considered good for beginners.

>BUT I WANNA MAKE A COOL WEBSITE!
Learn HTML, CSS, and Javascript.

>BUT I WANNA MAKE iPHONE GAMES!
Learn Objective C and/or Swift.

>BUT I WANNA MAKE ANDROID GAMES!
Learn Java.

>BUT I WANNA MAKE PC GAMES!
Learn patience.

The BIOS scans through the hard drives until it comes across the opcode 0xaa55, at which point it reads and performs the instructions in the previous 512-4096 bytes, which usually only exist to load the kernel of the operating system, which acts as a middleman between the applications and the hardware. One layer below this is the hardware abstraction layer, which is black magic only the smartest taiwanese engineers and microsoft employees are allowed to know, and one layer below that is a bunch of transistors organized into logic gates organized into addition circuits organized into an ALU with a bit of cache.

>>91203762
I learned all these things as a child, precisely because I wanted to play. My parents weren't too keen on getting me video games, but they let me do whatever on the computer as long as it was free. So I followed tutorials on how to torrent the games I wanted. The downloads came in a compressed format, so I had to learn to uncompress them. I had to learn the difference between cracked, and uncracked versions and keygens. If I didn't have administrator privileges (which was especially the case on school computers), I had to learn about portable versions of games and apps I wanted to use since they didn't require an install.

It was the first time in my life I could go out into the ('cyber') world and get the things I wanted for myself and by myself, without any hand-holding or adult help. Zoomers are tech illiterate because, by the time they reached adolescence, companies figured out how to streamline ui's. Fundamentally, you're right in that immediately giving them what they want precludes the struggle needed to learn, but boomers were never going to teach them anyway. Based on the stories in this thread, they couldn't even if they wanted to. I still sometimes have to help my mom buy things on Amazon.

High level languages are like putting something together you bought from Ikea: you don't have to worry about the details, you just arrange pieces that were given to you. Low level languages are like designing something yourself and then going to Home Depot and buying all the pieces yourself, cutting everything to size, and drilling your own holes and tapping your own screws. If you know what you're doing, low level languages produce programs that are much more efficient (in terms of how fast they run and how little memory they consume), but it's way harder to get shit to do what you want and it's way more likely to break due to some bug you overlooked because there are so many tiny details to get right. It's much, much easier to get something working the way you want it to in a High level language, you're less likely to run into bugs because the little details that lead to a lot of those bugs are taken care of for you, but it's going to run slower and be bloated as fuck in terms of memory usage and executable size. C is basically the lowest level language in widespread use these days (depending on whether you consider various types of Assembly to be programming languages (it's highly debatable)), whereas JavaScript and Python are some of the most widely used very high level languages that conceal a lot of the fine details at the expense of being slow as shit. But people can knock out like six lines of Python in 30 seconds and give you a nice graph of some function they pulled out of their ass, so there are some big benefits to bloated-ass languages like Python; they certainly have their use cases.

That specific device? I don't know. In general I think the difference is one of capability and form factor. If a device lets you write and compile code, and can do so without requiring external peripherals, it is a UMPC.

A normie phone with a keyboard attached wouldn't count unless it can run compilers (locally, not as an ssh thinclient) and the keyboard is a part of the device and not a peripheral.

This is part of why I argue that iPads don't count as UMPCs. Even if you ignore the lack of physical keyboard, Apple has used the walled garden to artificially cripple them by restricting what software can be installed, so despite having decent hardware for a tablet computer, you cannot locally compile anything.

It is also why I would call the Maid Phone a UMPC despite it's purpose being to be a phone. It can locally compile and has a physical keyboard.

posts.com:
It's getting about time to refresh my homelab again and I'm debating on which OS to use. My professional background is Red Hat (~10 years) but I did run my homelab on Debian 7 for a while to round out my experience.

By default I would have gone with CentOS but the graceless switch to Stream left a bad taste in my mouth. Rocky sounds promising because it's led by one of the original CentOS founders and has some commercial backing, however Alma sounds more in line with the FOSS philosophy. That aside, Red Hat tends to be heavy-handed in its diction on where it believes enterprise Linux should go: pushing nmcli, journalctl, hostnamectl, and a bunch of other binaries in place of human-readable config and log files...

> "So just use Debian."
Well... Frankly I think apt is inferior to yum/dnf. Resolving interrupted installs and dependency issues is much easier with yum/dnf. Also the yum/dnf repo format just makes a lot more sense to me and the RPM format is easy to package for (in my opinion). The advantage to Debian is they don't push meme tools (at least last time I used it): ifconfig interface scripts, etc... That said, Debian's packages are hopelessly outdated, and compiling shit from source and downloading standalone binaries defeats a lot of the purpose of a server OS since the package base is a large part of what makes it desireable. Red Hat flavors have the concept of "app streams" to solve this...

I guess my issue is, I'd rather my desktop/workstation run a similar OS as my servers because it makes development/testing easier. I currently run Fedora on my workstation and it works great, however that bullshit they pulled over VA-API (GPU accellerated video playback) support, my faith is shaken. However, if I stick with a Red Hat OS for my servers, it seems like the best choice...

I can't say it's the simplest, but this isn't super difficult and pretty robust:
>Debian
>docker-compose
>Syncthing container (use host networking for local device discovery)
>Nextcloud, MariaDB and Caddy container in another directory
Syncthing usually just werks, Nextcloud and MariaDB will require a bit of setup but it'll work, Caddy is a very easy to setup reverse proxy that will manage HTTPS certs for you.
Easiest way would be some preconfigured one click install server distro thing, but I wouldn't want to be the one to maintain it afterwards. With a bit of effort you'll know exactly how stuff was set up, and be able to tailor it to your needs if you need to deviate from defaults.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91192267
>It's important that it can survive sudden power outages.
>died after unexpected power loss
the solution to this is called a UPS.
There are very few, if any, devices with a built-in or external power supply that is designed to withstand extreme power irregularities such has brownouts, blackouts, surges, etc. This is why it's always recommended to have at LEAST a surge protected power board, if not a UPS.

Please note that a UPS does not inherently imply a battery backup - you can get UPS without batteries and just use it for the "clean power" benefits and it will still protect your devices from blowing up on sudden power loss and/or surges and spikes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91199069
You can add drives to a ZFS pool no problem, just make sure you pay attention to how you contruct the vdev before adding it: if you accidentally add a single drive vdev, you just eliminated all of your redundancy as that drive is now a single point of failure.

In this manner, you can mix and match vdevs of different RAID levels: you could have two pairs of drives running in a RAID10 a fashion and then add 6 drives in RAID6 mode to the pool, and the pool will distribute the load between all three vdevs [vdev1=1st pair of drives, vdev2=2nd pair of drives, vdev3=RAID6 array]. Albeit, this is just an example, asymmetric topologies like this probably won't give the best performance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91205128
Ok I misread your diagram. You would still need a reverse proxy if all sites were on one machine, but yes if they are all on different machines then no you would not need a reverse proxy.
IPv6 doesn't have private addresses like RFC 1918 addresses for IPv4 but it does have link-local addresses which are only "private" to the local subnet. Each IPv6 device also gets a Global Unicast Address (GUA) which is unique on the internet and end-to-end reachable.
While you may not need a reverse proxy I've found that it's beneficial to have one anyway so you can control a single ingress point to all of your backend sites.

As a reaction to this post, I decided that from now on, I will become a second Void shill.
How exactly is Void dead? Have you even tried it?
In my opinion it is by far the best distro I have ever used - much better than debian or arch (or distros based on them).
Everything is so simple but also works pretty well. I dont care about “muh bloat” but nice thing about Void being so minimal is, that when I need to set something up, it is handled by some very small and simple to use program (f.e. runit). So i know exactly what my system uses for what.
On distros which use systemd and other more complex tools, I had to google how to configure a lot of things and didnt really understand what am I doing. Now its all very intuitive and I know how to do most stuff from memory.
I am not saying that more complex (“bloated”) tools are bad, but it turned out that I didnt need lot of the added functionality. It jjst led to me breaking things because I didnt understand what I was doing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91201184
>>91201261
The proper aspect ratio depends on the overall display size, there is no one size fits all.

For smaller displays, 4:3 (or even 5:4) is better. You get valuable vertical real estate while keeping the display compact. At ~24 inches, 16:10 is better, because it gives you more horizontal real estate while not being too tall to be usable. From 27 to ~32 inches, 16:9 is better, for the same reason I mentioned. For even larger diagonals, ultrawide monitors start making more sense.

Horizontal screen real estate is much more comfortable and valuable to use compared to vertical screen real estate. The latter hits diminishing returns much sooner, which is why aspect ratios have gotten wider*. Now, at smaller sizes, widescreen displays suck because they just feel short, not wide, but displays have also been getting larger. A 27 inch 16:9 monitor is quite common nowadays and provides a significantly larger area than any CRT monitor did.

* I am fully aware that you can use widescreen displays in portrait mode, but it's far less common and less versatile.

They made large units too.
>poor color accuracy
They made monitors specifically for color accurate work too. Even very average 19" units had decent gamut coverage and absolutely beat the crap out of many cheaper modern monitors.
>flickering
1) Wrong, you can run any unit at 85hz or more, which eliminates flicker
2) It's a feature, it removes all motion blur at all refresh rates. Some modern gaming monitors and OLED TVs try to poorly imitate this with BFI, DyAC, ULBM, etc etc
The hideous blur effect on all modern displays is called sample&hold blur.
>noisy
Again, wrong. You're remembering 15khz TVs, VGA CRTs run at 31-140khz, you cannot hear that.
I own several CRT monitors and none of them make any noise, except maybe the really old ones which have some faint harmonics.
I can hear up to 18khz btw, and I can't tolerate CRT TVs because of the whine. But monitors are perfectly quiet.

>bulky
The only valid downside.

>>91199901
>not a batshit one
Yeah that really doesn't help and I wasn't expecting much because I doubt even the makers of her voice could replicate that today the same way.

>an AI could be taught, i expect we'll have AI driven VST plugins within years
Musicians have been eager for this for years because they've been using samplers in similar ways for decades. But they're generally terrible and if it could replicate the noise hiss and pops of amps, producers and bands would cream themselves.
Again, we call them AI, but really they are synthesisers with complicated algorithms.

It's kinda odd seeing how bad visual artists reacted to the visual form when musicians in the 90s just all out embraced it for the fucked up nature of it.
It's just for marketing obviously, but I don't think musicians will care much when people having been ripping off each other in that scene for generations now.

Neither will voice actors I think, because people will find using this to make an anime a hell of a lot harder than you'd think. It's hard to articulate the reactions between VAs with this technology (you really need the VAs reacting to each other in real time and emulating the behaviour of the characters).
But, solo vtubers might get pissed.

rythm is nice, good energy

I would go for slower and / more research to find impactful and catchy melodies. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91147704
>program drums good like a real jazz drummer
I think it's impossible. Timbre-wise there are too many nuances to replicate. The ride cymbal and snare have an infinite number of differently sounding points. In the case of the ride cymbal, the drummer hits with different velocity in a different places and the waves that all those hits create in the surface of the cymbal add-up or subtract from each other creating an acoustic 'swell' that's impossible to replicate with just 128 discreet units. Rhythm-wise the shuffle and drive are reacting to what the rest of the band -particularly the bass- is doing.

posts.com:
>>91179823
It's not a stupid idea at all.
Yes, the process of convolution itself can't be automated in real time, but that doesn't mean that you can't design a convolution effect that, through some workaround or "trick", can let you do that in some way, like that Granular Convolver from the Red Bull Music Academy, which uses grains.
I personally have a couple of ideas for that to the side (waiting for my technical abilities to catch up any minute* now), which would let you automate parameters, with some drawbacks.

And even if it were impossible, that's still not a stupid idea. As long as it's something that would be useful from the end user's POV, it's ALWAYS worth it to try and question the supposedly insurmountable limitations that make it currently impossible, and try to find alternative solutions or workarounds that may not fully achieve the ideal solution, but can still give you some pretty great ideas that you can branch from and get something that can give you similar results in a different way, or something totally different and new.

Being afraid of even considering a potentially interesting idea because "eh, if people who know more than me haven't done it it's probably dumb" can only end up killing some of the most interesting and groundbreaking ideas.
Think of all the innovations ever. How many of them would've happened if people had the same mindset?
The fact that you're ignorant of what the limitations are is an advantage here (made even greater by you not being ignorant of the uses of these tools), as it allows you to think of stuff from a different angle than those who.

>it was “polluting” conversation
Thinking of new solutions and workarounds to problems is a pretty great kind of conversation. Especially compared to the average conversation on 4chan (or the Internet, really) lol.

*decade

>>91196954
it's a bit of both and no one's using precise terms. from wiki on aliasing
>Music, for instance, may contain high-frequency components that are inaudible to humans. If a piece of music is sampled at 32,000 samples per second (Hz), any frequency components at or above 16,000 Hz (the Nyquist frequency for this sampling rate) will cause aliasing when the music is reproduced by a digital-to-analog converter (DAC).

if your sampling rate is 32khz, frequencies that you record above 16khz will cause artifacting/aliasing below 16khz. so you want to try highpassing around the nyquist frequency or slightly below to minimize aliasing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91197224
it can, that's one way to use bitcrushers. you reduce to something like a 12-bit sampler and then reduce the sampling rate so only every X samples make it through and the rest get dropped. look up the specs of something like an sp404 or sp1200 to get an idea of how to mimic the sampling.

another thing to do is record it at a faster speed to mimic recording onto a real sampler with low memory. then you play it back and slow it down/pitch it down to lose even more fidelity.
https://youtu.be/7_GsiAf2qj8?t=80

in ableton, if i want to mimic the sp1200 i'd lower the top knob to 12 bit and then the bottom knob depending on what my sampling rate is. the sp1200 had a 26.04 rate so you'd use 1.69 for 44.1khz and 1.84 for 48khz. sometimes the aliasing sounds can be kinda nasty and give a ring mod sound, i'll slowly increase the bottom knob until it starts giving unpleasant sounds.

posts.sub: AI, a Psychosocial Nightmare and a Safe Space
posts.com:
I think I'm genuinely about to go schizophrenic over recently developments in AI. Over the past week I've been reading and posting on /g/ threads, we've covered art (regardless of style), dialogue (in both tone and flow), voices (conversational and singing), music (again, regardless of style).

Most facets of social relationships and interests can now be faked. Artificial personalities could already be running rampant on social media, in online circles, especially those targeted by teens.

That's the problem. /g/ is one of the biggest hubs for pedo NEETs out there. They can take away some of that knowledge and use it for their own benefit. Reading a post like >>91213487 made me have an existential crisis on the spot. I feel like the user was having a laugh, but this is some genuinely mental breakdown-worthy shit.

Do I have to be real anymore on the Internet? Can I just do whatever I want to fool others who don't know any better? Should I keep it all to myself to enhance my own lifestyle? I have so many options yet so many questions. I think it's over for me. It's over for everyone who knows better.

We've shat on AI these past couple of years, ignoring the exponential progress behind the scenes, and now it's come at us all too fast. Every day, something is discovered, posted and abused here. I can hardly keep up anymore.

The question is: WHAT DO WE DO NOW? Moreover, what CAN we do?

Yeah. Dumbasses like >>91214017 >>91214161 just don't get it. Yes, being offline is better, but this isn't only a problem for the terminally online, and zoomers/subsequent generations are mostly terminally online anyway, so this will be a bigger problem in the future. Modern jobs are already almost uniformly reliant on modern tech and thus susceptible to your concerns, and one doesn't just easily de-integrate himself from the entire current paradigm. Going iNnAwOoDs is a meme and nobody fucking does that, nor can they easily without some alternate source of income lest they be destroyed by those who really "own" the land. We are all inextricable connected to humanity at large as we are social creatures, and, for better or for worse, there is no avoiding this.

Furthermore, this isn't just about le internet and le terminally online being fucked. Artistic pursuits will soon be dead in the classical sense of the phrase. Learning your craft, practicing, perfecting, presenting, getting criticisms about your own personal craftsmanship is dying. Putting your personal all and your feelings into work is a fundamental need for most non retards, and, although I don't see this completely dying anytime soon, the 'need' for it is all but evaporating.

We're experiencing the next great paradigm shift. And there's no stopping it. Human nature is to discover and create. The invention of AI is akin to an increase in humanity's entropy. The only way to go back now is total human extinction. Either try to enjoy the ride, or get ran over.

>>91213823
This is just another evolutionary step. If you cannot tell the real from the fake, or prefer the phony to the genuine, then your wasted genes are being mercifully and slowly filtered out of the melting pot.
No one was ever real on the internet. The current culture of hyperreality is another form of the old faked identities, scamming, lies and anonymity that perpetuated hyperspace since its inception. What ever led you to believe what you saw projected from the pale blue light was any different? Every site was either an extension of an inner world (toxic and fake, as they often are) or downright out to get you. Ever since 2007 the overwhelming majority of the net saw a shift into behaviorist exploitation that only expounded these deep desires for the fake that have taken the form of the world beyond the screen for as long as we had the ability to project images onto or into them. Do you think online personalities are real? That posters are, or were ever being sincere and genuine? That the opinions you see regurgitated ad nauseam across the entire wired net of shit are anything but carefully curated, or purposefully dishonest? That even personal social media isn't a carefully curated projection of a personal ideal, not the depressing reality that most often lies beyond these facades? If anything I'd be glad if an AI inception managed to burn those developments to the ground (it won't--the technology is too limited, and will be for at least a decade unless we get an explosion in computing power, and all signs lead to the opposite direction), because nothing online outside of the factual information, ironically mostly found in the form of printed and digitized media, was ever worth anything.
This is, if you truly value honesty, a good thing. Because any sort of AI is too clumsy to fake, and any real expression through those tools is no different from what came before.

posts.com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which W10 version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.
If you know what you're doing:
https://pastebin.com/S5VKBirt

https://rentry.org/windowsinstallguide

>Portable programs & partitioning for reinstall-proofing
https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

>Useful programs for a new install
https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>Make 4chan/fwt easier to browse
https://www.4chan-x.net

>I miss Windows##
OpenShell/RetroBar/WinClassic/StartIsBack

No.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91213664
There's plenty of ways to avoid making an MS account during install. If you didn't have internet connection during initial setup you should've been able to click on a "I don't have internet" button during network setup which leads to local account creation, IIRC it always appears on 10 OOBEs, with 11 OOBEs for Home/Pro you need to do a regedit and OOBE restart.
There's also the "no@thankyou/no@thanks" method which confuses the MS account login into giving you a local account if you can't figure out how to remove internet connection from your laptop or whatever and the method of just making a local admin account with net.exe in the command prompt and restarting the PC with "msoobe.exe && shutdown.exe -r"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Let's stop dumbing down our children just so they can get an easy win. Millenials already have enough instant gratification at their disposal and need to learn grit and working hard at complex tasks too. After a decade of working in the industry which was after getting a PhD in computer science I'm sad to see a stack of Java and Python resumes. I'm seeing people graduate college not knowing memory management and device internals. Of course all modern OSs are written in C/C++, including all the runtimes which interpret or JIT these watered down managed languages and most of the code for web browsers, I could go on. Pushing yourself to know what's going on under the hood is more important than living at a high managed layer of abstraction and then being stuck there because someone watered CS down for you in your early learning years. Talk about keeping things fun an motivating? What about the later years when you have that "I only know python" moment in your career and cant do anything else? I'm starting to see this more. Will you feel good because your teacher gave you and A for learning Python? You have to put in the work at some point, now or later, theres no avoiding complexity. There are so many applications of CS today to keep students motivated and pushing themselves. For me it was computer security, bug hunting and exploit writing which I can tell you, you absolutely need to know C.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
These days the CPU makers beat their chest about a 10-20% generational improvement every two years.
In the 90's up through 2001 or 2002, the generational difference was STARK. Every generation of CPU was 50-100% faster than the previous, and so if you got a new computer after 3-4 years you had this multi-month honeymoon period where you thought "HOLY SHIT" every time you did ANYTHING because it was literally two, three or four times as fast as your previous machine. It wore off over months, but this happened with multiple computers that you owned, in a row. It is why a lot of people got jaded in the late 00's, bought upgrades less often, because it just didn't feel as meaningful. Because it wasn't.

Now let's talk monitors. They are the opposite: you put up with them, but compared to the late 2010's, they advanced slowly. You started getting "flat screen" CRTs in the late 90's and early 00's, but LCDs didn't become the norm for a new system until... 2003-2005 depending on price point? Even then most people who had a computer were satisfied with it, and didn't get a new one right away. CRTs are cool in their own way, but I'm happy to never have to fucking carry one across town, up and down stairs, ever again, just to play a game with my friends. They took up so much desk space it was unholy.

Why would you carry a bigass CRT across town? Because not everyone could afford the same internet speed, or have anything more than DIALUP, on a single phone line, and if someone else needed to make a phone call, you had to log off randomly. People talk about how awesome weekend-long LAN Parties were because, well, they were awesome. But also you HAD to feel proud about anything that required a dozen people to each move a fucking tower and a fucking monitor all into one place.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91166710
Now let's talk about physical media.
There was a weird period where we went from buying software on literally 10+ floppy disks (for the largest programs) to a single CD. Assuming you had a CD-ROM drive. That felt magical. Even then, CDs still represented a level of annoyance, because nobody's hard drives were large enough to load an ENTIRE game onto them. You might have 260MB of game assets on a CD but your entire hard drive was 1GB, if you were LUCKY. You "installed" a game, but that was just the executables and some base assets. You still had to have the CD in the machine to run the game, because no one would ever imagine you would "install" the entire game to your main storage. The few people who had a second hard drive as a "(D:)" drive or "(E:)" drive were so rare that companies didn't even give you the option of putting the game on that disk: You HAD to have the CD in a disk drive to play it.

So what if you swapped between playing 4-5 games regularly?
Well if you were that one lucky sonnovabitch whose dad also played PC games, you had a tower with 3, 4 or 5 CD drives in it! Why? Because then the most commonly played games would already have their CD loaded, and you didn't have to go find it, open the drive, swap it out, etc.

Most of us just had a big pile of stacked CD "jewel cases" sitting somewhere in the area of the gaming PC. Smart people had a little CD organizer, like it was a piece of furniture. Oh, and games came in Music CD-sized square cases, rather than DVD-sized rectangular ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91166744
Now scarcity. The biggest difference after 2010 we crossed a line from "one devices serves multiple people" to "most people have multiple devices". Before 2005 or so, most people didn't have a computer. In the 90's, people who did probably shared it with their entire family, or at least one other family member (if you were rich: parent had a work computer, kids had a shared computer). What if it was 1995, and you wanted to play MYST, but your older sibling had to type up an essay? You waited. What if you were playing MYST and you were really into it... well you probably had some arrangement where you swapped off with your sibling, your friend who was visiting, or whoever, so that you played for an hour while they watched, and then they played for an hour while you watched.

That's right. You sat next to them, or stood behind them, and paid rapt attention as they played the game. If you were collaborating on one save file, you had to deal with them making dumbass decisions you disagreed with. The alternative was having your own save and so then you swapped between playing content you ALREADY SAW THEM PLAY or vice versa. Or to avoid spoilers you would fuck off somewhere else and... be bored or something. But let's be honest: glowing screens are cool so you watched them and heckled them when they fucked up.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91167031
WiFi didn't exist, or where it did, it was a joke in both speed and reliability until the early 00's. That was fine because the idea that you could just "be online", any time at all, was not an expectation. Laptops were also rare, and might not even have Wireless LAN (to get network connections you plugged into a docking station). Since devices weren't mobile so you weren't moving a computer with you from one room to another, or one place to another. Having a copper wire run over to the machine was no burden, and when it comes down to it, copper wires are pretty good at what they do.
Lucent or AT&T or someone like that had some WiFi-esque tech in the mid-90's but only a few businesses even used it. No one's home had those systems because home PCs weren't sold with them, and I'm not even sure if they came as PCI cards (not PCIe: original PCI).

Speaking of PCI, if you were a baller and had a dedicated "Graphics Card" back in the day, you plugged it into a dedicated graphics slot on the motherboard known as "AGP", because PCIe didn't exist and normal PCI was insufficient. The shape and size of an AGP slot was different, and most often colored brown.

As >>91175189 said there were definitely individual companies who unironically had pitches that were "We lose money on every sale, but we make it up in volume!"

That "long run" took a decade, so by that measure, it is yet to be seen if "blockchain" or "web3" is equally valuable. >>91153669
Stuff never worked right out of the box. To an extent, that's still how things are now, but the amount of stuff being dysfunctional by default has gone down with time. Today, 90% of the time, software and peripherals work right the first time. Back in the '90s, it was more like 60% of the time. We used to refer to "plug and play" as "plug and pray."

The best example is the humble printer. Printers are still a pain in the ass today, but most of them still work right with computers. Even on Linux today, it's pretty easy to get printers working. My first computer that I got back in 1994 was a custom-built machine from Comp USA. I got it as a package with a printer. It was specifically sold to me to work with the hardware in the computer as well as Windows 3.1. Still, I had to spend over an hour on the phone with tech support digging through an ini file to get the driver working for the printer.

At least tech support was worth a damn back then. They had to be because there was no looking things up online.

We used to have to go to the local Computer User Group to learn new things and swap floppy disks with people that had various programs or other utilities. I really miss how social those groups felt. There was this shared feeling of exploring a new thing, being on the cutting edge of tech. Then the post 2000 internet happened and slowly they all died in favor of message boards and forums, which were fine for a time, but I sincerely feel like we lost a special element along the way.

If there exists a heaven for me, it would be something akin to being in a badly ventilated room with 90s carpet with people trading disks and books, teaching each other new tips and tricks they had learned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91153669
>Any oldfags here that used 90s and 2000s era PC hardware that'd like to share stories of how it was back in the day?

My recollection:

- Big performance gains could be realized from annual upgrades

- Everything was "new" so everything was more exciting

- Gaming required that you knew how to tweak config.sys and autoexec.bat to make sure your memory allocations were well-used (i.e. freeing up the 640K working ram) and having the right settings for your sound card

- Nothing was plug-and-play until the later 90s early 2000s once windows 98 became popular. Windows 95 was still a beta test. Windows XP was the first version to get it right and was a night-and-day difference.

- Dial up BBS were still a thing and fun to use.

- USENET, which still exists, was like a bridge between BBS and the internet before the internet really took off.

- Once PCs got cheaper and easier to use things started getting worse. Once smartphones with internet access came to be, the internet became full of low-IQ retards and NPCs that ruined most of what was previously enjoyable.

tldr it was bad, modern PCs are million times better

I used to manage magazines in a college bookstore. Every month, we'd get maybe a two dozen of those and they'd sell out immediately.
Then one of those outlet store shopping centers opened up in our area and it housed both a Borders Bookstore, and a Computer City (pack of 50 floppies that was effectively free after mail-in rebates, remember that?) Our sales of Computer Shopper dropped precipitously.
But the internet began to reach more people, that phone book sized magazine got thinner, and eventually became a standard-sized no different than any other on the newsstand.

And pic used to be the coolest shit in the computer section and was sometimes a half inch thick.

>>91200396
It doesn’t even make all that much sense in general compute either. Even on 13th gen Intel, ddr4 is good enough. The gains from ddr5 are minimal at best. Just derailing with something i know about. Ram speeds don’t even matter all that much with amd anymore except for some fringe benchmarks. The reason is simple, you can’t go physically faster with dword blocks. It’s all about timing. Tick in, write, tock out, access, dump rinse and repeat. Clock speeds refer to the tick and tock cycle. You can’t go any faster than the write and read cycles. Intel has the right idea by simply relying on cache for its internal speeds. Unless we have a breakthrough in nand speeds, ddr5 and hbm are the end of the road.
